workIndustries.question: What industries have you worked in? We are curious how mechatronic you were or not.

bestCoopExperiences.question: What was your favourite co-op experience? What made it such a good experience?

responses.response: 2nd coop. Small personable team, high velocity, cool tech, learned a lot.
Working for a biotech startup & being able to develop a product
Working as a robotics research assistant at SickKids. The nature of the job, I just enjoyed working with the dVRK robot and that setting in general
Sinclair Interplanetary by Rocket Lab! It was a good environment in terms of work-life balance and support from the other employees, and the work was really interesting.

Just having the ability to experience 6 different work environments throughout the course of this degree was my favorite part of co-op. I have made a lot of friends and connections through this experience.
Data Analyst at Super.com. Great pay, very flexible hours, great culture
Worked at a startup, the people made it the best co op.
Working in California
Working in the bay area for my last co-op. You get more money, better experience, better coworkers, and the state is beautiful.
Working at a rich company in California. Exploring the beauty and nice weather of California while getting paid well and travelling a lot overseas for free for my company.
ODI (Ontario Die International). Lots of coops of the same year that I interacted with daily. Also ping pong table in lunch room was goated.
I had an amazing time at Christie Digital with the best co-op students you can dream of
Built my own startup
Working in California in the summer. The weather changes everything
Versa Networks, a well-established startup in California allowed me to spearhead development in big customer features from the beginning and develop me into the developer that I am today.
My co-op at Tesla. I had a great team of people who I loved working with, and I got the chance to work on interesting, impactful projects while developing new skills.
Last 2 coops, making friends with colleagues and coops

One of my favourite co-op experiences was doing research into AI expert systems at IBM. While I had other offers for higher pay and/or more convenient locations, the experience I gained and learning that I was able to accomplish while surrounded by a team of highly skilled and exceptionally driven individuals pushed me to advance myself far faster than I ever thought possible. This led to both a fun internship experience and an experience where I learned far more than all my other co-ops combined.
Test driving sea-doos
Work where I was treated as a full-time instead of given odd tasks
Nuvation Energy, great mentorship, smart people, lots of hands-on work

Working at Tesla - very smart and interesting people, all driven towards the same goal. Was the most hardworking team, where I learned the most and still connected with everyone on my team and adjacent teams.
Working at ATS, made great connections
immediate impact, lot of trust in me
Trexo Robotics, got to own a complete mechatronics project and see it to completion
Apple, development

At a gaming company. I really loved video games so it was my ideal workplace. They gave interns free access to all their games and we still got to keep access to the games even after our internship ended.
Hardware

My favorite co-ops have been at startups, since there was always something to do, and the full-timers and mentors were always willing to help out and offload tasks. It was great since they gave you ownership of the projects you took on.
Apple. The novelty and the money
Apple - Product Design fun
Employer gave me 3 big projects to do where i learned a lot I hadn't ever worked with before and overall, just trusted me with big decisions.
Mondelez. Free Oreos
Working at Sea-Doo in Quebec. Had a great work-life balance with some really nice and fun people.
Manulife, the opportunity to work on a meaningful project
Final coop term, working at Viryl Tech. Had a lot of autonomy to design, develop, and test products.
Skipped 3 coop terms (with e-coop) to work on my startup. Very worth it, learned a lot more than I would have as an intern.
Atomic Semi was great. Great coworkers, amazing project, an environment conducive to making really cool stuff.
Christie Digital
My last co-op, since they gave me a large amount of freedom to pursue my own research projects
electrical work was fun! I liked working in-person and debugging
Figure AI - got to work at a fast paced startup working with humanoid robots

My favourite co-op was BRP Inc in Quebec, my role was Vehicle Dynamics Intern and I got to ride the off roading vehicles, be part of a living learning community with people across the world, I learned so many new technical tools, cultural knowledge as well as interpersonal relationships

I really enjoyed my term at Arc Boats in California. Being able to live somewhere else for 4 months was such a unique experience, and the people there are so different than here in Canada/Waterloo. There is a unique life about working and living somewhere like LA that I really enjoyed.

Robotics engineering co-op in astrophysics at the NRC. I got to design a telescope calibration system from the ground up and travel to New Mexico to install it. Loved learning about space, having on a personal project, and working with smart people.

My favourite coop experience was my 4th coop where I worked at a robotics startup. It was my first firmware/embedded job, and because of the small size of the company I was able to take ownership of whole features/initiatives rather than just work on less meaningful tasks.
Trend Micro, great company, great work culture, great people
Deeptrekker, I had a really good supervisor, and i worked on interesting robots, which gave a me a greater appreciation for Mechatronics.
Finally getting a job in robotics! The company was very passionate and hard working
Last co-op - was living in SF, not doing engineering work at all, in a really exciting field
Working at Tesla. The insane depth of knowledge that you can gain from the engineers and the freedom to define your own work

waterlooWorksThoughts.question: How did you find your jobs?

responses.description: Direct application through company careers page

top_methods.dominance: Overwhelmingly dominant - used by 99.2% of respondents

top_methods.importance: Second most common - 36.1% used personal connections
Third most common - 33.6% used professional networking

networking.combined_usage: High networking usage with multiple overlap

insights: Waterloo Works is the primary job discovery method for nearly all students
Networking (referrals + LinkedIn) is used by a significant portion as supplementary method
Traditional job search methods (external applications, job fairs) have low usage
Students appear to use multiple methods (totals exceed 100%)
University co-op system provides strong job placement infrastructure

internshipTips.question: Any tips for landing an internship?
responses: Don't get discouraged during the first couple of terms! The later co-ops tend to come easier with more experience. I personally have submitted over 500 applications on WaterlooWorks, eventually something will stick.
Take pride in stuff that you have accomplished & listed on your resume
join a design team
take any interview you get even for practice, for software: Hackathons, Leetcode, Conferences, Projects, Passion
Grind outside of school
Grind side projects or join design teams
Turn an interview into a conversation rather than them just asking the questions.
Make connections!
Apply more, get referrals
Join design teams!
Work on design teams and have a string portfolio
Keep spam applying. Sometimes, it might just work. Also, don't neglect interview prep.
Have friends in high places.
linkedin connections!
Be passionate about what you do. Don't do shit for the money or networking.
Grind side projects & design teams, portfolio on resume, LinkedIn is pretty good
Get involved with design teams or personal projects
Reach out to interesting people on linkedin and chat about what they do, when there is a common interest, they are more likely to help you find a role somewhere at the company.
Apply to jobs even if you think you're not qualified.
Do a lot projects. Hackathons
Work on your portfolio! Build it with projects
Tailoring our resume to specific jobs, keeping a 'master list' of experiences/projects

Join a design team in 1A and do as much work as you can with it. Specific, relevant experience on your resume is what will get you a job. The theory you learn in and out of class is only useful if you use it to do something.
Your parents are Staff Engineers at Nvidia
Don't be weird, shower before your interviews
Grind hard early even during your current co-op
Get your resume reviewed on r/EngineeringResumes / peers / mentors
Make connections, everyone knows someone, and people want to help!
do something outside of school worth talking about
Spam apply with a portfolio
Make a project portfolio, attach it with all applications. Being yourself is more important than being perfect in interviews.
Your first one, try reaching out through as many avenues as possible. You want to cast a wide net. Same for applications on WaterlooWorks.

If you want top tier jobs, be willing to work 'stepping stone' jobs in random cities that might not pay as well to gain relevant experience in that field. Dress well in interviews, tell stories, be very likeable. Work on your people and speaking skills. A lot of times even having 11/10 technical kowledge won't save you.

Design Teams and Personal Projects - show off in your Portfolio, take a 'less desirable' first coop to build foundational skills such as manufacturing experience or drafting experience instead of jumping straight into design - you probably wont be a good designer at the start.
Look at the job descriptions of jobs are you are interested in
Get your LinkedIn in good shape and put it on your resume
Join design teams. Show people you are interested and passionate through your actions not your words.
Aim high, don't be afraid
Have a cool portfolio with interesting and unique things, even if they aren't the most impressive things in the world.
Do cool things
Work for it, portfolios are a must, get your resume reviewed with an upper year
Do personal projects even if they're small - shows initiative which apparently interviewers like
Fill out as many applications as you can. Have personal projects
Work your ass off, put in the time to be technically competent, and be very thorough

All experiences matter, try to do your research and put your best foot forward. You miss all shots you don't take so don't get intimidated and apply to everything you are interested in! Passion and willingness to learn matters more than proven experience

Send emails and reach out to people at the companies/industries you're interested in ! Demonstrated interest goes so much further than just 'having a better resume'. I cannot stress the amount of hiring managers that have told me they'd much rather hire someone with good people skills and who's easy to work with than someone who is technically perfect for the job but lacking in people/interpersonal skills. You can teach/refine technical skills but you cannot change people's attitude/demeanour.
Work on projects relevant to positions

Get the look of your resume right, single column, no color, all black and white. Easy on the eyes of the recruiters. Get it reviewed a ton from senior trons and listen to what they say. If you wanna go to Cali, consistent design team involvement or URAs are the way to go
Get gud
just keep trying!
interviewers want to hear you yap about something you're passionate about

Be friendly in interviews, show that you're a real person and would be good to work with. Don't be afraid to ask questions during the interview and try to focus on or bring up your unique characteristics and differentiation from other candidates
Contact engineers through linkedin
Be at the right place at the right time. Join a design team and attend the design team specific recruiting events. Landed my last internship and full time job through these events.
Join design teams early and build strong connections
